awd_titl_txt: FW-HTF-P/Collaborative Research: Exploring Tools to Help Workers and Organizations Adapt to AI-enabled Robots
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will promote exploration of scalable tools to aid workers and organizations adapt to artificially-intelligent robots. In a sharp departure from current robotic systems that have to be programmed for a single manipulation task in a very tightly constrained set of conditions, venture-funded firms are designing and beginning to test qualitatively new robotic technologies that promise to flexibly automate entire classes of embodied tasks in widely divergent conditions. In this likely future, robots will adapt as readily to new repetitive manual tasks as a modern microprocessor adapts to new computational tasks. Such "learning" robots would clearly have profound implications for workers and organizations, but previous research on automation offers only limited guidance on how they will adapt. The researchers have recently begun a nationwide, four-year field study that will identify edge cases in which organizations and low-skill workers achieve unlikely yet systematic success, given the introduction of this disruptive technology. This will allow deriving design constraints for potential solutions from grounded theory, centering on the hard-won, demonstrably successful innovations of a suitably-diverse pool of informants. While existing research stands to unveil the mechanisms behind rare, in vivo learning successes to the world, this FW-HTF-P (Future of Work at the Human-Technology Frontier - Planning) award will assemble a world-class team of researchers who are committed to trying to expand and capitalize upon these mechanisms via new tools. This research has high-impact potential for organizations, lower-skilled workers and policy makers on how to expand and enrich work involving increasingly intelligent systems in the 21st century.

With AI in robotics as the technology, humans collaborating with robots as the workers, and organizations employing both the robots and the workers as the context of work, the team of researchers will specifically contact and convene a group of top experts in diverse technical domains including social media, massive open online courseware, crowdsourced knowledge repositories, peer assessment and coaching, user experience design and platforms for on-demand labor, crowdsourcing and innovation challenge execution. Beyond these technical disciplines, the researchers will invite policymakers and technologists, as the pathways to local success will likely be deeply intertwined with legal and commercialization processes. The researchers will begin by sharing very preliminary findings, research questions and objectives from the current study with a select group of such researchers who may have interest in a potential collaboration. The researchers will then extend formal invitations to a workshop to no more than ten potential collaborators. This workshop will be one day in length and will be described as an opportunity to explore and decide upon potential collaborative opportunities related to helping workers and organizations adapt more productively to general-purpose robots. The researchers will explore potentially new organizational theories that take perspectives such as: (a) accounting for success as a learning problem in which robots, workers and organizations learn from each other; (b) the character of learning infrastructures evident in various practices for adapting to learning machines acting as co-workers; (c) how the organization of such learning practices impacts skill changes, role transformations, as well as workers and organizations. The researchers will then solicit participants' input and commitment for tools to scale the successes inherent in the findings and select the tool likely to have the greatest benefit for the most Americans. The researchers will then jointly craft an FW-HTF-R (Future of Work at the Human-Technology Frontier - Research) proposal with interested collaborators that reflects a rigorous test of this tool in real-world settings. The ultimate goal of this project is to develop the necessary research personnel, research infrastructure, and foundational work to expand the opportunities for studying future technology, future workers, and future work at the level of a FW-HTF full research proposal.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The major goals of this project were:

  1. to develop a grounded understanding of how high-mix, repetitive manual work involving generalized AI robotics differs from similar work without these cutting-edge technologies;

  2. to develop novel theories and hypotheses regarding such work, particularly related to positive outcomes for low-skill workers and organizations;

  3. to gather and analyze nationwide data related to these theories and hypotheses; and

  4. to test the validity and utility of these collected findings via field experiments

We undertook the following activities in pursuit of these goals:

  1. Enlisted 8 robotics firms to participate in our study under NDA

  2. Observed 12 different sites over 698 hours

  3. Performed 51 site visits in small, medium, and large businesses all over the USA

  4. Performed 350+ interviews with frontline workers, supervisors, operations managers, facilities workers, corporate employees, and maintenance workers 

  5. Hosted a workshop with key stakeholders to investigate whether these findings implied a novel direction for technological development

Our specific objectives were:

  1. To understand the conditions in which organizations adapt constructively to qualitatively new forms of automation.

  2. To understand the conditions in which workers adapt constructively to qualitatively new forms of automation.

Our interim findings - focused on front-line workers - include:

  1. Most frontline workers adapt to increasing and unpredictable automation by reducing their resource burdens and dependence on any given employer. Failure means crisis. 

  2. Some frontline workers have what we term ?sensitivities? - a fascination or irritation with differing aspects of the work.

  3. These became evident through very small-scale improvement ?proposals? or efforts. Constructive adaptation requires these plus productive visibility to management.

  4. Technologies for resource burden reduction are common.
    We have not seen technologies for identifying and supporting worker sensitivities.

Relatedly, we: 

  1. Identified a preliminary set of ?sensitivities,? and organizational processes that correlate to better adaptation to new AI-powered robotics tools (see attachment for slide deck on this project).

  2. Hosted a workshop featuring key stakeholders to discuss findings and determine whether a large-scale proposal to develop new technologies should be written based on these findings. (See attachment for event details)

  3. Determined that a clear, large-scale proposal for a follow-on NSF grant to develop technology focused on these findings was not evident by the conclusion of this workshop.

This project involved two postdoctoral associates and two doctoral students. Each participated for between six months to two years, and received extensive hands-on training in research design, participated in data collection and analysis, workshop preparation and writing up findings. 

One article referencing the work has been published (see this short article in MIT Sloan Management Review: https://sloanreview.mit.edu/article/working-with-robots-in-a-post-pandemic-world/). Another is currently under review at a top journal, and three additional manuscripts are in preparation for submission.

This was a first-of-its kind field study looking at real-world deployment of next-generation, high-mix robotics in several key areas. Attributes that make this study special, which could impact the discipline:

  1. Longitudinal study (not cross-sectional)

  2. Multi-sited study (not single-sited/single company)

  3. Multiple, diverse technologies (not just one technology under observation)

  4. Ethnographic (does not rely solely on surveys or phone interviews)

  5. Appreciative (seeks conditions that explain or predict success)

We hope this effort encourages more firms to share their data and to work with academics. We also hope more technology creators develop AI and robotics that keep their human impacts in mind. And finally, we hope this effort encourages other researchers to study the impacts of robotics and AI tools in the way we have with this study.

 Findings from this study may help companies find better, more efficient ways to train workers and to integrate robots.

Material from this data collection and workshop delivery effort is now incorporated into three graduate seminars (one PhD and two Masters) at UC Santa Barbara.

This study is a crucial step in measuring the impact of new robotic and AI tools, and to helping foster a human-centered approach when developing and integrating AI into the workforce. Findings from this study and others like it may help companies to develop technologies with a solid understanding of how those technologies will impact the workers whose jobs will be transformed. 

We were granted a no-cost extension for two reasons. The first is that data collection took longer than expected, given the complexities associated with executing separate NDAs for each of our field sites. Secondly the Covid-19 pandemic led to severe travel and contact restrictions that greatly hampered our ability to complete our data collection. A one-year extension allowed us to complete the required analysis for a productive workshop.
